title: Uncovering Stationary Atoms in Liquid Metals
summary: Researchers have made a groundbreaking discovery in materials science by observing that not all atoms move within a liquid, even at high temperatures. Using transmission electron microscopy, scientists from the University of Nottingham and the University of Ulm studied molten metal nanoparticles, such as platinum and gold, supported on graphene. They found that some atoms remain stationary, strongly bonded to point defects in the graphene. These motionless atoms significantly influence solidification processes: when few are pinned, crystals can grow and solidify the metal, but when many are fixed, they disrupt crystal formation, leading to a corralled supercooled liquid state. This research sheds light on the complex behavior of liquids, which has been less understood compared to gases and solids. The findings have implications for various technologies, including aviation, construction, and electronics, as solidification determines material properties. Additionally, the study utilized the SALVE instrument to explore wave-particle duality of electrons, revealing how electrons can both image materials as waves and fix atoms as particles. This work builds on previous achievements in filming chemical reactions at the atomic level, advancing our ability to control and understand material transformations.

background_read: This article discusses advanced research in physics and materials science, focusing on the behavior of atoms in liquids. Solidification is a critical process in nature and technology, influencing everything from ice formation to metal manufacturing. The study builds on prior work by the same team, who have filmed chemical reactions at the atomic level. Using cutting-edge tools like transmission electron microscopy and the SALVE instrument, scientists explored atomic motion in molten metals, revealing unexpected stationary atoms. This discovery challenges traditional views of liquids and opens new avenues for controlling material properties. The research highlights the interdisciplinary nature of science, combining chemistry, physics, and engineering to address practical challenges in industries such as pharmaceuticals and construction.
